user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY)
  /* FreeBSD style */
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    cpuset_t cur_mask;
    /* The should get "anonymous" mask/set. The anonymous mask is always
       a subset of the assigned set (which is a subset of the root set). */
    if (0 == cpuset_getaffinity (CPU_LEVEL_WHICH, CPU_WHICH_PID, (id_t) -1,
                                 sizeof (cur_mask), &cur_mask))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT
      ret = CPU_COUNT (&cur_mask);
#else  /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
      unsigned int i;
      ret = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE; ++i)
      {
        if (CPU_ISSET (i, &cur_mask))
          ++ret;
      }
      if (0 == ret)
        ret = -1;
#endif /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Use 256 times larger size than size for default maximum CPU number.
       Hopefully it would be enough even for exotic situations. */
    static const unsigned int mask_size_cpus = 256 * CPU_SETSIZE;
    const size_t mask_size_bytes = CPU_ALLOC_SIZE (mask_size_cpus);
    cpuset_t *p_mask;

    p_mask = CPU_ALLOC (mask_size_cpus);
    if (NULL != p_mask)
    {
      if (0 == cpuset_getaffinity (CPU_LEVEL_WHICH, CPU_WHICH_PID, (id_t) -1,
                                   mask_size_bytes, p_mask))
      {
#ifndef MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (mask_size_bytes, p_mask);
#else  /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (mask_size_cpus, p_mask);
#endif /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
      }
      CPU_FREE (p_mask);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S */
#endif /* HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I flagged the conditional blocks and alternative preprocessor branches that can produce unreachable code paths in some build configurations or contain conditions that are constant at the point they are evaluated. These fragments should be investigated for possible unreachable code (e.g. constant conditions, mutually exclusive configuration macros, or dead alternative branches).

Other parts of the function do not appear to contain statically unreachable statements that need investigation: the initial declaration and initialization of ret, the final check and return (if (0 >= ret) return -1; return ret;), the cpuset_getaffinity call sites themselves, the CPU_FREE call, and the surrounding #if/#endif scaffolding are all either straightforward runtime checks or controlled by configuration macros (i.e. they are present or absent depending on build-time definitions rather than being unreachable within a given translation unit). These elements therefore do not require further inspection for Rule 2.1 beyond the listed suspicious fragments.
